conclusion: The particle starts from rest, so the initial velocity v(0) = 0.
From 0 to t0/2: The acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0.
From t0/2 to t0: The acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0.
From t0 to 3t0/2: The acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0.
From 3t0/2 to 2t0: The acceleration increases linearly from -a0 to 0.
The velocity v(t) is the integral of the acceleration a(t).
From t0/2 to t0: v(t) = a0 t0/2. At t = t0, v(t0) = a0 t0/2.
The position x(t) is the integral of the velocity v(t).
From t0/2 to t0: x(t) = a0 t0^2/4. At t = t0, x(t0) = a0 t0^2/4.
From 3t0/2 to 2t0: x(t) = 0. At t = 2t0, x(2t0) = 0.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = t0 and t = 3t0/2, where the position is a0 t0^2/4.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = 3t0/2.
